comment.author: 50162466@N00
comment._content: How can that be looking East? Where's Hyde Park?

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: The building on the right still stands on the corner of King Street and the Pitt Street Mall. Looking up the hill to the east is the spire of St James Church. The steam tram was heading up the hill to turn right into Queens Square on its way to Rose Bay. "The fatal card" is on the marquee of the Theatre Royal left.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 45104424@N00
comment._content: Cate Cahill The northern end of Hyde park is at Queens Square, which is at the east end of King St. You would not see the park from King St.

comment.author: 25877962@N07
comment._content: Yeah, you can see St James and then, beyond that, the Hyde Park Barracks

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: that photo isnt from 1892. St james spire had a broach added in 1894-95, which is evident in that photo. maybe late 1890s?

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales

comment._content: Thanks uminarampart! I investigated further and The Fatal Card played at the Theatre Royal in 1895 and 1898.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: 'The Fatal Card' (advertised in this pic) ran at the Theatre Royal, Sydney in March 1895 and again in September 1898 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13985011 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71317591 ; The digitised newspapers indicate that the firm Page & Notting, estate agents, etc (whose sign is seen here on the building on the rhs) split in ca. 1896. Page & Co. continued at 139 King Street, whilst W.A. Notting moved on to 159 Pitt Street. I can't as yet find a business notice advising of the split, however a number of SMH adverts and notices indicate this, eg. see their respective adverts here (lower rhs column) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14102859 . So I'd say that this pic dates from ca. February-March 1895.
